problems.title: f(x) = x^2 is not uniformly continuous on R
problems.problem: Prove that. $f(x) = x^2$ is uniformly continuous on $[0,1]$ but not uniformly continuous on $\mathbb{R} $.

problems.title: f(x) = x^2 is not uniformly continuous on R
problems.problem: Prove that. $f(x) = x^2$ is uniformly continuous on $[0,1]$ but not uniformly continuous on $\mathbb{R} $.
problems.hint:
• A continuous function on a compact set is uniformly continuous.
  • As $x$ is increasing, the graph becomes more straight and hence in the functional value it takes a big jump, which suggests not uniform continuous on $\mathbb{R} $.
problems.solution:
To show that $f(x) = x^2$ is uniformly continuous, let $\varepsilon > 0 $ be given. We need to find $\delta = \delta (\varepsilon ) > 0$ such that for any any $x,y \in [0,1]$ \[ |x - y| < \delta (\varepsilon ) \implies |f(x) - f(y)| < \epsilon . \] Consider \begin{align*} \vert f(x) - f(y) \vert & = \vert x^2 - y^2 \vert \\ & = \vert (x-y)(x+y) \vert \\ & = \vert x-y \vert \cdot \vert x+y \vert \\ & \leq \vert x - y \vert \left( \vert x \vert + \vert y \vert \right) \\ & \leq 2 \vert x - y \vert . \end{align*} Choose $\delta (\varepsilon ) = \frac{\varepsilon }{6}$. If $\vert x - y \vert < \frac{\varepsilon}{6} $, then \begin{align*} \vert f(x) - f(y) \vert \leq 2 \vert x-y \vert < 2 \frac{\varepsilon }{6} = \frac{\varepsilon }{3} < \varepsilon . \end{align*} Thus, the function is uniformly continuous on $[0,1]$. Note that the same proof can be adopt for any bounded set, that is, the function is uniformly continuous on any bounded set.
Now to see that the function is not uniformly continuous on $\mathbb{R} $, to the contrary assume that $x^2$ is uniformly continuous on $\mathbb{R} $. So for any $\varepsilon > 0$, we can find $\delta (\varepsilon ) > 0$ such that \[ \vert x - y \vert < \delta (\varepsilon ) \implies \vert f(x) - f(y) \vert < \varepsilon . \] Choose $\varepsilon = 1$, so there exists $\delta = \delta(\varepsilon ) > 0$ such that \[ \vert x - y \vert < \delta (\varepsilon ) \implies \vert f(x) - f(y) \vert < 1 . \] By Archimedean property, choose $n \in \mathbb{N} $ such that $\delta > \frac{1}{n}$. Take $x = n$ and $y = n + \frac{\delta}{2} $, then \begin{align*} \vert x - y \vert & = \left\vert n - n + \frac{\delta}{2} \right\vert = \left\vert \frac{\delta }{2} \right\vert > \frac{1}{2n} > \varepsilon , \end{align*} a contradiction. Thus, $f(x) = x^2$ is not uniformly continuous on $\mathbb{R} $.
